docs.snippet: Whatever doubts the world's intellectuals and politicians may raise about America's war on terror, the world's people do not seem to be voting with raised fists -- yet.    Despite a war in Afghanistan that has dropped thousands of bombs and killed...
docs.lead_paragraph: Whatever doubts the world's intellectuals and politicians may raise about America's war on terror, the world's people do not seem to be voting with raised fists -- yet. Despite a war in Afghanistan that has dropped thousands of bombs and killed some civilians, there have been no devastating anti-American riots; there is forbearance, as sympathy for the victims of Sept. 11 still lingers.
docs.abstract: Portraits of United States as lonely, self-absorbed bully taking out its rage about Sept 11 terrorist attacks on defenseless Afghanistan are on rise from intellectuals and editorialists around world; more and more, war is being seen abroad as 'America against Osama,' and not as Bush administration portrays it, 'all of us against terrorism'; intense rush of sympathy following Sept 11 seems to have faded everywhere but in Tony Blair, prime minister of Britain who continues to jet around globe to recruit support for cause; photo (M)

headline.main: More and More, Other Countries See the War as Solely America's

docs.snippet: An article on Sunday about the world's changing perceptions of the United States since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks misstated the nationality of Eduardo Galeano, a journalist who wrote of Guatemalan victims ''sacrificed not by Muslim fanatics but...
docs.lead_paragraph: An article on Sunday about the world's changing perceptions of the United States since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks misstated the nationality of Eduardo Galeano, a journalist who wrote of Guatemalan victims ''sacrificed not by Muslim fanatics but by terrorist militias supported by the successive American governments.'' He is from Uruguay, not Mexico.
docs.abstract: Correction of November 4 article about world's changing perceptions of US since September 11 terrorist attacks
docs.section_name: Corrections; Washington; New York and Region

docs.snippet: Ecuador clinched its first-ever World Cup berth with a 1-1 tie with Uruguay at Quito, a draw that also clinched a spot in the 32-nation field for Paraguay.     Bolivia upset Brazil, 3-1, in La Paz, a loss that kept the four-time world champions from...
docs.lead_paragraph: Ecuador clinched its first-ever World Cup berth with a 1-1 tie with Uruguay at Quito, a draw that also clinched a spot in the 32-nation field for Paraguay. Bolivia upset Brazil, 3-1, in La Paz, a loss that kept the four-time world champions from clinching the final automatic spot in the 10-nation South American region. The fifth-place team advances to a playoff against Australia. Brazil (8-6-3) must beat Venezuela (4-11-1) in its final game of the qualifying round on Nov. 14 to wrap up fourth place.
docs.abstract: Ecuador clinches first-ever World Cup berth with 1-1 tie with Uruguay (S)

docs.snippet: With the United States' spot in next summer's World Cup secured, Sunday's final qualifying game in Trinidad and Tobago is a good time for Coach Bruce Arena to test players with the potential of making the roster for the final stages.     Defending...
docs.lead_paragraph: With the United States' spot in next summer's World Cup secured, Sunday's final qualifying game in Trinidad and Tobago is a good time for Coach Bruce Arena to test players with the potential of making the roster for the final stages. Defending better in midfield is one area in which the Americans need to improve. Chris Armas of the Chicago Fire has been effective as the defensive midfielder for years and is expected to be the top player there again next summer. He will miss Sunday's game to be with his wife, who is pregnant.
docs.abstract: US soccer team to play Trinidad and Tobago in final World Cup qualifying game (S)

headline.main: AMERICAN MEN TO FACE TRINIDAD AND TOBAGO

docs.snippet: The American goalkeeper Kasey Keller injured his left ankle during practice in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and was dropped from the roster for Sunday's World Cup qualifier at Trinidad and Tobago.     The American goalkeepers available for Sunday's game...
docs.lead_paragraph: The American goalkeeper Kasey Keller injured his left ankle during practice in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and was dropped from the roster for Sunday's World Cup qualifier at Trinidad and Tobago. The American goalkeepers available for Sunday's game are Zach Thornton of the Chicago Fire, who has six international appearances, and Nick Rimando of the Miami Fusion, who has none.
docs.abstract: American goalkeeper Kasey Keller injures his left ankle during practice in Fort Lauderdale, Fla, and is dropped from Nov 11 World Cup qualifer at Trinidad and Tobago (S)

headline.main: Keller Hurts Ankle; Will Miss Qualifier

docs.snippet: A Brazilian delegation to the World Trade Organization talks landed in Qatar today, hoping to lay the groundwork for new accords even as trade liberalization was losing momentum around the world.     Trade accords are a priority for Brazil as it...
docs.lead_paragraph: A Brazilian delegation to the World Trade Organization talks landed in Qatar today, hoping to lay the groundwork for new accords even as trade liberalization was losing momentum around the world. Trade accords are a priority for Brazil as it tries to pare its huge current account deficit.
docs.abstract: Brazilian delegation to World Trade Organization talks lands in Qatar, hoping to lay groundwork for new accords even as trade liberalization is losing momentum around world; trade accords are a priority for Brazil as it tries to pare its huge current account deficit; but even with Brazil's currency, the real, down around 25 percent since January, exports have barely budged as global economic slowdown has scared investors away (M)

headline.main: Brazil Gives Priority to Reaching Accords

docs.snippet: Trade ministers from 142 nations will meet in Doha, Qatar, today for a conference of the World Trade Organization. Their agenda is much the same as the ill-fated ministerial meeting in Seattle in 1999, when attempts to bridge the gap between poor and...
docs.lead_paragraph: Trade ministers from 142 nations will meet in Doha, Qatar, today for a conference of the World Trade Organization. Their agenda is much the same as the ill-fated ministerial meeting in Seattle in 1999, when attempts to bridge the gap between poor and wealthy countries' priorities blew up in a cloud of tear gas. The whole world has an interest in seeing this gathering turn out better. With the world's terrorized economy stuck at a standstill, the time is ripe for a cooperative, international push for growth through trade. The ministers' goal in Qatar is to launch a new set of comprehensive trade negotiations. During the original Uruguay Round, which led to the creation of the W.T.O., rich countries pledged to open their markets to textiles, crops and other basic exports from the developing world. There has been some progress in that area, but arcane customs rules, unnecessary red tape, stingy quotas and anti-dumping programs still keep poor nations' exports out of wealthy markets. Now protectionist politicians are trying to erect more barriers by exploiting concerns about border security and food safety.
docs.abstract: Editorial, commenting on upcoming international trade summit in Qatar; notes agenda is much same as at ill-fated ministerial meeting in Seattle in 1999, but that with world's economy in state of stagnation time is ripe for cooperative, international push for growth through trade; says world has interest in seeing that upcoming gathering turns out better (S)

docs.snippet: THE SETTING -- More than 100 people are crammed into two rooms at Mammalinda restaurant on West 52nd Street in Manhattan, and they are waiting anxiously for the broadcast of the World Cup qualifying match between Ecuador and Uruguay. A victory or a...
docs.lead_paragraph: THE SETTING -- More than 100 people are crammed into two rooms at Mammalinda restaurant on West 52nd Street in Manhattan, and they are waiting anxiously for the broadcast of the World Cup qualifying match between Ecuador and Uruguay. A victory or a tie would send Ecuador, population 13 million, to its first World Cup finals. This is a big, big deal. The fans are a bundle of nerves, pacing, drinking strong coffee, wine and beer in, of all places, an Argentine restaurant. Many wear the yellow, red and blue jerseys of Ecuador's team. No Uruguayan fans are in sight, but one guy is wearing a Yankees jersey.
docs.abstract: Article describes scene at Mammalinda restaurant in Manhattan as fans await broadcast of World Cup soccer qualifying match between Ecuador and Uruguay; photo (M)

headline.main: Small Country, Big Day, One Ecstatic Moment

docs.snippet: World trade ministers say they fear that they will deliver a shock to the world economy unless they agree to liberalize trade at their meeting here. But the only shocking thing may be if they manage to agree on anything at all.    The World Trade...
docs.lead_paragraph: World trade ministers say they fear that they will deliver a shock to the world economy unless they agree to liberalize trade at their meeting here. But the only shocking thing may be if they manage to agree on anything at all. The World Trade Organization, the umbrella trade body, is sometimes described as the ultimate capitalist club, but it is far from exclusive. It has 144 members -- with the addition of China and Taiwan this weekend -- including many of the poorest as well as the richest countries. The United States, Uruguay and Uganda have exactly the same voting power, which is none.
docs.abstract: Reporter's Notebook column on World Trade Organization summit in Doha, Qatar; says that representatives fear they will deliver shock to world economy unless they agree to liberalize trade, but that only shocking thing may be if manage to agree on anything at all; notes trade organization operates by consensus since voting is forbidden, meaning that smallest holdout can in principle sink weightiest agreement; photo (M)

headline.main: Equality at Trade Talks: No Country Gets a Vote

docs.snippet: Goalkeeper ZACH THORNTON was the only United States player to distinguish himself during Sunday's scoreless tie with Trinidad and Tobago in the last World Cup qualifying game for both teams.     Thornton was a last-minute replacement for KASEY...
docs.lead_paragraph: Goalkeeper ZACH THORNTON was the only United States player to distinguish himself during Sunday's scoreless tie with Trinidad and Tobago in the last World Cup qualifying game for both teams. Thornton was a last-minute replacement for KASEY KELLER, who hurt his ankle in practice last week. Thornton made at least two difficult saves in the second half to bail out a rather vulnerable defense for the Americans, who finished third in their group behind Costa Rica and Mexico.
docs.abstract: Article discusses United States tie with Trinidad and Tobago in last World Cup qualifying game for both teams (M)

headline.main: Thornton Played Well, Even if the U.S. Did Not
